Content-Transfer-Encoding: quoted-printable

Derek,

You wrote:
>Well, the only two attributes of the XML that deal with=
 presentation are the two "hint" attributes in the neuron tags, and as Coli=
n suggested, those could simply be optional.  Include them if you want to g=
raphically represent the networks...leave them out otherwise.

Got it.  Rem=
ember that there will be thousands upon thousands of these structures, poss=
ibly millions.  Small things can add up pretty quickly, even optional attri=
butes.  If you are using a good compression algorithm (like I am using zip =
in mine), then perhaps the cost is not so bad.

It might also be worth reme=
mbering the "presentation hints" are something that can be dynamically gene=
rated from the network.  So storing the data in the XML might not be necess=
ary if the "display" mechanism did the "depth" calculation on the fly as it=
 was working to present the network layout.

I just want to ensure the thin=
king hits these options.  I am fine with the hints being optional and prese=
nt.  I also want to be sure the conversation contains "things to think abou=
t" as all these systems start co-evolving!  ;^)


Jim




  ----- Original =
Message ----- 
  From: Derek James 
  To: neat@yahoogroups.com 
  Sent: Tue=
sday, March 30, 2004 10:46 PM
  Subject: [neat] Re: Phenotype XML


  --- I=
n neat@yahoogroups.com, "Jim O'Flaherty, Jr." 
  <jim_oflaherty_jr@y...> wr=
ote:
  > I am concerned about your representing "presentation" information =

  >with your "structure" information.  Would it not be more effective 
  >=
to have a second XML document detailing "presentation" details, and 
  >hav=
e that document "point" to the "structure" XML document?  

  Well, the onl=
y two attributes of the XML that deal with presentation 
  are the two "hin=
t" attributes in the neuron tags, and as Colin 
  suggested, those could si=
mply be optional.  Include them if you want 
  to graphically represent the=
 networks...leave them out otherwise.

  All other information in XML is re=
levant to its actual structure and 
  function.

  >That way, those who wan=
t to work strictly with data structure and 
  >have not care for the presen=
tation, are not burdened with the 
  >presentation data.  

  Just leave ou=
t the "hint" tags.

  >Additionally, there will be other types of presentat=
ion that will 
  >likely be created later.  I am assuming you would not wan=
t to add 
  >this presentation data to this XML, right?

  Not as an integr=
al part of the XML...but if someone else wanted to 
  include optional attr=
ibutes to assist with graphical representation, 
  that could easily be ign=
ored when parsing...that'd be fine.

  Personally, I'd prefer one basic for=
mat for network XML, with 
  optional attributes, rather than keep track of=
 two forms of XML. 

  Derek
